summary: With their beloved Andy preparing to leave for college, Woody (Tom Hanks), Buzz Lightyear (Tim Allen), Jessie (Joan Cusack), and the rest of the toys find themselves headed for the attic but mistakenly wind up on the curb with the trash. Woody's quick thinking saves the gang, but all but Woody end up being donated to a day-care center. Unfortunately, the uncontrollable kids do not play nice, so Woody and the gang make plans for a great escape.

reviews.content: Always makes me tear up at the end even 13 years after man

An incredible film full of comedy, action, high stakes, and emotion. The characters are entertaining and compelling, the story is excellently written, it's impressive how much the movie delivers. It blew me away, definitely worth checking out.

Toy Story 3 is an absolute gem of a film that has captured the hearts of both children and adults alike. As someone who grew up with the original Toy Story films, I was excited to see how this third installment would fare. And boy, was I not disappointed.

From the start, the animation quality was top-notch, with every character and detail beautifully crafted. The storyline was equally impressive, delivering a tale that was not only entertaining but also emotionally resonant. I found myself invested in the fate of Woody, Buzz, and the rest of the toys as they navigated the perils of life in a daycare center.

One of the things that impressed me the most about Toy Story 3 was its ability to balance humor and heart. There were plenty of laugh-out-loud moments, but the film also tugged at my heartstrings, especially towards the end. Without spoiling anything, I'll just say that the final scenes left me misty-eyed.

Summary:
	A continuation of Toy Story 1 and Toy Story 2, Toy Story 3 encompasses Andy, the owner of the toys preparing to go off to college. Andy hasn't played with the toys for years, so the toys build up suspicion that he will dump them out. As he attempts to put them in the attic, the toys, except Woody, end up being donated to Sunny Side, a daycare. Delighted that they will be played with, the toys reject Woody's requisition to return to Andy, but the kids at the daycare end up being aggressive. As they plan to leave the daycare, they discover the corrupt system. Woody then returns to the daycare to save his friends. 

Analysis: 
The main theme of this movie is friendship. The toys including Jessie, Woody, Buzz and Rex have always been together and for each other. However, throughout the movie, conflict arises about Andy moving to college which separates them from each other. However, the friendship returns and aids to their rescue from the daycare and the dumpster. For example, after Lots of Huggin refused to press the button that would've saved all the toys, they became hopeless as they accepted the certainty of their death falling in the pit of fire at the dumpster and stretched their hands to each other. Despite the realization of imminent death, the toys appreciated their friendship. Soon after, the three alien kid toys came and grabbed them and saved them from being burned. This scene is significant evidence of the theme of friendship. It showed to the audience how sticking together and believing in each other is a beautiful thing. It shows how friendship is a key factor in life. 
	Toy Story 3 also sends a message throughout the movie. It shows to the audience that everyone grows up and moves on, but the little events in someone's life are always apparent. Andy has not played with his toys for years, and as he came to throw his toys away, he hesitated and wanted to put them in the attic, except Woody, with whom he holds a great deal of memories. He places him in the college pile. Although Andy realizes he doesn't need these toys anymore, at the last scene of the movie as Andy decides to give those toys to Bonnie, he sees Woody in the box and hesitates to let him go. But he does, and then plays with Bonnie. Him playing with the toys for the last time in a while reflects on his love for them, but also on moving on.

Critique:
The strengths of this movie are for sure more than the weaknesses. The movie can communicate to the viewers the emotions of every character with each conflict and event. The plot supports the main theme of the movie. Acknowledging that this movie stands out for kids the most, the movie did a great job of sending positive messages, educating the kids on the concept of moving on and entertaining the kids with the different plot twists and the overcoming of the obstacles that came in the way of the toys. It is exciting and fulfilling for kids. 
The weaknesses of this film are directed towards the logical concepts but are not too significant since this is a kid's movie. One of them is the trendy contradiction of the strength of these toys. For example, the toys could not easily move the garbage plastic bag having almost 8 toys inside yet were able to move a tv in the dumpster scene. Also, it made no sense that Woody was able to leave the daycare so easily in the beginning of the movie seeing no guards or obstacles except being seen by humans while as the other toys tried to escape, they faced multiple levels of security Lots of Huggin had installed. Another thing is the daycare. The kids, when inside the daycare, play with the toys, and then they are called to go outside to also play. In most daycares, there are certain systems and educational lessons for these kids at daycare. 
Despite the criticism above, I would rate this movie a 4.73 out of 5.

The toys are back in town with Disney Pixar's second sequel to the film that made them a household name. The animation is as dazzling as ever, and the voice work and writing are spot-on (even though this is the least funny of the three, seeing as the jokes are spread thinner this time around). But what makes this memorable, and what has always made Pixar stand out, is its enormous heart. The emotional connection we've developed with Woody, Buzz, and the gang pays off in starling and sometimes scary ways. There are moments here that will have your heart racing and your eyes watery. The ending is a beautiful coda for this fantastic film series, reminiscent of the opening dialogue-free montage in 'Up'. The filmmakers say this is the end, and it feels like it. But they should be proud of the legacy they've left behind with these wonderful films. With this one they've ensured a classic franchise, and not only is this one of the best films of the summer, it's one of the best films of 2010

Toy Story 3, is a very rare movie, because it had a huge inspiration on Stephen King's "The Shawshank Redemption". If Lotso play the role Samuel Norton and Big Baby as Byron Hadley, then it will be very similar to the book.

Toy story 3 is an example of everything I like to see in a film. The humour isn't overly excessive. The characters develop throughout. None of the characters feel excluded from the story and they have to work together to reach their goals. The ending is one of the few times I have genuinely felt emotional while watching an animated film. Therefore, I give this film a  5/5

Another delightful addition to the Toy Story franchise, #3 is nonetheless not without its problems. There's some dark stuff in there. Lotso the strawberry has some real anger (and honesty) issues. He's a bitter, manipulative bully who couldn't see that his kid replaced him quickly cuz of how much she loved him as a toy. Besides, it was more the parents who overlooked the toys than anything Daisy did.
The garbage truck inci...dent (thought I was gonna put something else, didn't ya?) was pretty hairy, too. And there are some holes you either choose to ignore or let bother you- Ken tied up? a 15, 16, 17 yr. old still having such toys? But I still had a lotta kid in me at 16. 
Can we at least put Randy friggin' Newman out to pasture, at least for kids' movies? Yeesh. 
Sweet and apt ending, and a generally good flick I'm sure I would've liked just fine as a kid. 3.4 stars

And it never hurts to totally nail the landing...

This film defined my childhood completely, and deserves all the acclaim it gets.

To me, Pixar have never yet made a bad film, even their weakest Cars is actually very good. Like a lot of people here, I grew up with and loved the first two Toy Story films and still love them. As is consistently the case with Pixar they are superbly animated, sophisticated and had great characters. Toy Story 3 somehow managed to do the seemingly impossible, while its Toy Storys 1 and 2 have a special place in my heart, this film was even better.

Perhaps Toy Story 3 isn't the most original of the trilogy or of the Pixar films, but that made little difference to me. While the darkest of the three, it still maintained the predecessors' heart and charm, and overall it was just an amazing film full-stop from start to finish, and easily one of the best of the year.

The animation is just superb here. Hardly a surprise though, as the animation was phenomenal also in Toy Storys 1 and 2, but to me it was just as sophisticated and as colourful here if not more so. I also loved the music, that said I don't think it is the best Pixar score(Up) or best score of the year, but it is almost certainly one of Randy Newman's better efforts and I liked the You've Got a Friend in Me repeat.

The pacing is just fine as well, and the story is tremendously engaging with plenty of humorous, tense, exciting and genuinely affecting scenes. The ending especially resonated with my entire family, especially my brother, while the scene in the dump is for me Pixar's most intense scene.

I was also delighted with the film's script. The dialogue was always witty and sharp, none of it felt forced in any way. There was the brilliantly judged humour- Buzz speaking Spanish was just one of the highlights and the beginning alone had about 5 or 6 laughs- and also the poignant parts that avoided being overly-sentimental and mawkish.

Another strength is in the characters. All the main characters are as likable as ever, Woody is still determined, Buzz is a sheer delight, Jessie(though I actually like her) is more tolerable here and Mr Potato Head is hilarious. But the new characters are just as wonderful, the baby is both creepy and cute and I felt for him at the end, the cymbal monkey especially for that shriek is one of Pixar's scariest characters, Lotso looks cuddly but is actually shady and bitter with an unrelenting past and Ken is cool without being bland or annoying.

As ever, the voice work is brilliant from all involved, not just from Tom Hanks and Tim Allen but also from Ned Beatty whose crusty demeanour fitted Lotso like a glove.

In conclusion, a truly brilliant film and a fitting conclusion to an amazing trilogy. 10/10 Bethany Cox

The toys are back in business, and they won't stop to get what they want. "Toy Story 3" is a nostalgic movie for the people who grew up with the franchise, and a delightful flick for the kids of today.

As Andy is preparing for college, his favorite toys accidentally get donated to a daycare instead of being stored in the attic. It is truly amazing that the story tellers at Pixar can continually add a fresh take on these characters with every sequel. All the voice actors do a great job continuing or introducing their characters. Lotso is a well written villain with a sympathetic backstory. The animation is terrific and it is amazing how the look of these characters have changed since the first Pixar movie. The ending will bring tears or warm-fuzzies depending on your mood. Highly recommended movie and a great ending to one of the best trilogies in cinematic history.

Still my favourite film ever. A good end to the trilogy (that isn't to undermine Toy Story 4 in any way) with loads of emotion. `Of all my respect, Toy Story 3 is my least favorite of the series. I'm not saying that like it's bad. I really loved the ending with Andy, and everyone's arcs works out really well, and the animation is beautiful. The reason it's my least favorite, however, is because the dark tone really scared me as kid, Lotso terrified me, and the movie itself, in my opinion, is kind of dated because all the scenes in Sunnyside were so disturbingly unwatchable to me. Overall, this movie was a great conclusion, and superbly should've that way.

After a decade of waiting for a third movie, Toy Story 3 released and it did not disappoint, some people thought because it was long ago since the 2nd, that the 3rd would not be as good. And In my opinion, Toy Story 3 is my favourite out of the 4, and it has the same memorable characters, with new enemies.

Man‚Ä¶.did Pixar kick off this decade with a bang with another 5 out of 5 movie! The last couple of Pixar movies have been some of my personal favorites, with Cars more suiting as a guilty pleasure than anything else. However, I think Toy Story 3 is better than all of those films by a good bit.  First, the story and plot. It's a prison break movie, which I'm already a sucker for. Combine that with the Already great storytelling of Pixar, and you have a chefs kiss for it! Next, the villain. Lotso is probably the best Pixar baddie since Syndrome. He has a great backstory, and for the majority of the film, he wins, which is kind of insane. Now, let's talk about the animation: it's perfect, not too much to talk about there. And the ending, OMG the ending! It's such a great way to end the movie.  If I had to nic pic one thing, it's probably the plot line of making Buzz a space ranger again, that seemed a little lazy. But that means we got Spanish Buzz, the funniest part of the film, so it doesn't affect the quality of the movie at all. The question really is is this the best Toy Story film? To me at least, I like the second more, the sole reason being that I like the characters introduced in that one better than this one. Not to say the new characters are bad in anyway, but are they going to leave as big an impact as Jessie or Bullseye? Yeah, me neither. This is a great film, and a perfect way to end this franchise‚Ä¶.too bad they made another one, but that's for another review. Go to Disney+ and watch the next perfect Pixar flick!

Toy Story 3 was pretty good l. Not as good as the first two but it was still a pretty solid feature. I really enjoyed the characters in this movie. They continue to be so fun and entertaining to watch. I really love the villain Lasso and just love how he went from kind hearted to ruthless in the end. I also like the idea of a prison break out of a summer camp. And I also really like how they keep on bringing memorable new characters. And the ending of the film does put you on the edge of your seat. However even though I like the ending of this movie  I think it would've been better if it had a tighter good bye to Andy. I think it should've had a little bit more time to feel the emotion through Andy, Woody, and Buzz. But other than that I really enjoyed this movie. The animation is the best out of the other two and I really enjoyed spending more time with these characters. All in all good movie. 9.9/10
Another great movie in the Toy Story lineup that still has the charm of the original...well done!

Toy Story 3 is a masterpiece. An absolute f*****g masterpiece. It would work in any animation style‚Äì‚Äìheck, in any medium.

Here's the *true* plot summary:

In a daring bid to escape obsolescence, an assortment of children's toys find themselves trapped in a dystopic Panopticon operated by a psychopathic teddy-bear and his mutilated henchmen‚Äì‚Äìa manifestation of a bitter and regretful future they must either succumb to or resist with everything they've got.

"Bambi" this is not, and its many transcendent moments rival and surpass the best 'classics' of children's literature‚Äì‚Äìchief amongst them, a truly harrowing and heart-rending "incinerator" scene that strips the characters down to their plastic basics and leaves the viewer feeling as if they just completed a therapy session with Viktor Frankl.
My favorite of the franchise, Toy Story 3 is on a high quality level and an exciting story, it is simply brilliant this continuation.

The animation is gorgeous, as usual for the Toy Story franchise. I loved the Toy Story movies in general, but Toy Story 3 was, in my opinion, the best of them. It was the best ending that the saga could have got, for me. That's why I didn't like the release of another movie after this one. In addition, it is the most emotionally powerful movie in the saga. I bet you cried or are going to cry the first time you saw/see it.
I didn't think it was as good as the first two it was still really good but in different ways that the first two were.

A Perfect Tale of Adventure and Devotion
Since I felt none of the other reviews here do the movie justice, I became compelled to write my own. It is the most inspired film I have ever encountered.

The creators of Toy Story 3 have an imagination that is unparalleled. I cannot begin to compare any of the other animated movies that I have ever seen to it. It is a fantasy in an unconventional sense: aside from the talking toys, the environment and settings are typical; commonplace. Yet, the Pixar Team manages to cram every last drop of energy into the incredibly clever story and inventive plot devices out of just common household objects. The animation is so brilliant that it captures shading, lighting, and textures that have yet to be seen on film.

Then, Toy Story 3 becomes a beautiful elaboration on the first two, with very clever character development. Its maturity of relationships is concise but witty: Woody, the wise sheriff, leading the other toys with courage and finesse; a spaceman winning the love of a cowgirl; the loyalty of the dog, slinky; the grumpy married potato and his devoted wife; the superficial relationship of Ken and Barbie; the broken spirit of a lost teddy bear. At the same time, Pixar uses a metaphor that is so strong that it drives the audience to love these characters with all of their hearts. It is a similar emotional complex to a happy puppy who is brought into a home and has nothing on its mind but playing with its youthful owners. But these toys never age, and as its owners, once in their playful youths, leave for work and college, these toys still know nothing more than their youth and happiness of living to one day play again. As you leave for work every morning, your dog doesn't know where you go. And every day, he does nothing more than pray that you come back to see him, every day waiting for you to bring out the ball again for a game of fetch.

Finally comes Pixar's ability to integrate so many emotions - fear, love, action, and comedy, among others - with each having so much vigor in its own right, that the movie becomes a roller coaster of animation and adventure, wound together by the constant movement of setting and storyline, always keeping the audience guessing on what might happen next. It is a brilliant tale; a perfect movie for children and adults alike. I cannot wait to see it again.
visually beautiful animation, script I am not a fan of scenes that are very sad, even cool cast, this animation does not please me very much.

This third Toy Story movie was very good. Tom Hanks, Tim Allen, Ned Beatty, Joan Cusack, Don Rickles, Wallace Shawn, John Ratzenburger, Blake Clark, and the rest of the cast did a spectacular job in this movie. The plot to the movie was entertaining, adventurous, and humorous. It's a great movie for an entire family. If you haven't seen this movie yet, check it out sometime. It's a must see.

Most franchise-type movies keep handing out sequels until they wear out the audience. Toy Story keeps getting better and gives you more.
How could TS4 possibly be better than this?

It is a true testament to the world of Toy Story that Pixar can put out a second sequel and it not only rivals the first two films, but is possibly even better. It's also impressive that so many of us have become so attached to the lives of these fictional toys - surely credit goes to the writers, animators, and voice actors who have tugged at my heartstrings and opened my tear ducts in each installment. Toy Story 3 is a lesson in letting go, moving on, but holding on to what matters. It is marketed as a kids' movie, but is really a story for adults - it's all about the nostalgia of childhood and sentimentality for the simplicity of that time and the humour is witty enough for adults, too. I certainly don't want to give up Woody, Buzz, and the gang, so keep them coming Pixar!
Even though this movie is animated, it has some deep emotion and a really great story. Just as classic as the first two and most certainly worth watching.

Against all odds, it improves greatly on its predecessors. It blends comedy, adventure and drama in a poignant and emotional way. Its charming characters, emotive story and gorgeous animation make it another classic from Pixar, that will leave audiences emotionally satisfied.

I'm going to be very honest about this movie Toy Story 3 is a second squeal that also really works when I saw it and a sad and emotion ending when Andy was giving his toys to that little girl named Bonnie when he was about to go to college.

This second sequel works better than most at maintaining the story that was developed in the previous films. It manages to continue the storyline smoothly and introduce many new characters flawlessly. It is possibly more exciting and action-packed than its predecessors, and it focuses more on the theme of growing up and letting go of the past.
Beneath Toy story 3 lies the harsh reality that at some point you need to move on.
A really neat return of the series, and in my opinion was the true way to end the Toy Story saga.

Great piece of story telling, almost too good and in danger of becoming an adult film, but lots of fun for everyone.

While this is a good movie, I'm not sure it holds up over time.

We start with the awkwardness of missing almost a decade of adventures, followed by the "leave childish things behind moment" that leads to the actual adventure.

The boss baddie as a scorned mob boss feels awkward and the motivation of the minon toys is skeptical at best.

The core team is as good as it has been, but the obstacles are just lacking. With it being toys vs toys, it just feels like a normal movie instead of having the magic of them being toys contending with not being noticed in reality.

And the punishment of boss baddie feels super religious: as if we witness his sentencing to hell.

Like I said, good movie, will watch again: it's just not the previous movies.
Another great example of Pixar's work. Don't have to be a child to enjoy this film!
I loved this movie growing up and I still do even though I am 14

Worst toy story movie by far, lacks the bare essence of the franchise, with pure chaos and evil, this is the very worst the saga has to offer. Constantly putting you down, this dark movie shows a facet of Toy Story that frankly should've remained hidden, not a kids movie and certainly not a toy story film. Plus, you know who doesn't recognize Toy Story 3? Toy Story 4, which after the initial scene shows exactly how the end of the movie was reached and totally skips through the unnecessary evil and cruelty of this so called "kids movie". Wouldn't recommend, stay away from this if you're showing your kids the toy story saga and skip through to the much better Toy Story 4 movie.
